revdescription.para: This is a beta release for version 3.0.0. There are a lot of changes in this release and many of them impact the public APIs.

Changed the graph walking code to avoid recursion so that we don’t blow up the Java stack. This has changed the tree counts for some infinitely ambiguous graphs, but since there are ∞ many trees, the counts aren’t really meaningful anyway.
There are no technical changes in this release. The build system has been complete refactored.
This release includes another improvement in GLL parser performance and fixes for some small bugs in the graph rendering for forests produced with the GLL parser.
Additional small performance improvement in the GLL parser, small documentation improvements.
With an enormous debt of gratitude to @chriswhocodes, the performance of the GLL parser is much improved.

listitem.para: Another complete refactor of tree walking. With new metaphors this time. There are no more tree selectors or ForestWalkers, instead we have Arborists, either org.nineml.coffeegrinder.trees.Lumberjacks or TreeSurgeons, armed with Axes. The idea is that a Lumberjack clears a forest. The lumberjack walks through the forest sequentially returning all of the applicable trees. For example, armed with a SequentialAxe, the lumberjack returns all the trees. Armed with a PriorityAxe, the lumberjack returns the highest priority tree(s). A TreeSurgeon, on the other hand, extracts specific trees with no attempt to be sequential. The RandomAxe, for example, just makes random choices until a tree is found.
In the best case, where the parse is unambiguous, none of this matters, there is only one tree in the forest and it doesn’t matter who attempts to get it or how.
Presented with an infinitely ambiguous forest (one where the graph contains one or more loops), the lumberjack will return an unbounded number of trees.
When the prefix parsing feature is enabled, it is now possible to resume parsing with a different parser.
The ParseTree has been renamed GenericTree and refactored a bit. The new ParseTree class is only used during the search for a tree.
Provide tree selectors with all the paths, even those that are loops. The looping paths are always “other choices”.

Revised what constitutes “making an ambiguous choice” in the tree selector. When a tree selector has only a single, non-looping choice, it is still making an ambiguous choice. The other choice could have been made. (It remains unambiguous in the priority selector if the priority selector would have unambiguously made the same choice from all the available choices.)
Tidied up some tests; removed references to JUnit 4 classes.

Reworked tree construction. I’ve abandoned the efforts to return (some of) the infinitely many trees that result when there are loops in the grammar. Loops are never followed when there are other options.
Reworked the GLL parser. Removed a whole lot of cruft by using lambdas directly for the instructions.
Removed some arbitrary limitations on regular expression matches. Tested that they work for both the Earley and GLL parsers.
Removed some dead code, simplified some APIs, tidied up and improved the JavaDoc.

revdescription.para: Version 3.0.0c fixes a bug where a regular expression pragma would not successfully parse when the regular expression matched the empty string.

listitem.para: Fixed bugs in the “regex” pragma. It’s now supported and tested in both parsers.
Improved node and family IDs (they’re now local to the forest). Extended and improved the forest2dot.xsl graph stylesheet.

Added an option to analyze the grammar for ambiguity with Anders Møller’s ambiguity analyzer. (Note that thie analyzer jar file is included in the repository, but it isn’t bundled with CoffeeGrinder, you need to add it to your class path. It is bundled with CoffeePot.)

Completely reworked how trees are constructed from the parse forest. The new code divides tree building and tree selection (choosing among ambiguous alternatives) into different classes. The result is much, much simpler.
The parser attributes are available to the tree builder. The parser attributes used by NineML have been renamed to URIs.
The RuleChoice class has been removed. Tree selection can be done directly from the Family objects. A unique ID has been added to each family.

The parser supports a priority attribute for guiding the selection between ambiguous alternatives. If a particular family does not have an assigned priority, it’s priority can be computed as either the highest priority of any of its descendants or the sum of the priorities of its descendants.
Priorities are now integers, not floats. The parser option “priority style” controls whether computed priorities are maximum values or sums.

Priorities (and other parser attributes) may cause new nonterminals to be created when the parser is constructed. The NonterminalSymbol field symbolName can be used to distingiush between them (as can the symbol ID, of course). The getName() method always returns the canonical name.
The parse forest no longer exposes multiple root nodes. They can only exist before the forest is pruned.

revdescription.para: The default “sequential” tree selector will choose every node and ever edge at least once. For graphs without loops, this matches the number of parses reported. Tree construction from graphs that contain loops is challenging. The total number of parses reported does not take loops into consideration. (Graphs with loops have an infinite number of parse trees.) The tree selector tries to follow all of the paths once, but it may fail for pernicously looped graphs:

caption.para: A graph where X⇔Y, X⇔Z, Y⇔Z, X→’x’|ε, Y→’x’|ε, Z→’x’|ε,

revdescription.para: It will get many, but not necessarily all of the possible paths. The priority tree selector will always choose the path with the highest priority (if there is one). If all choices are made by a uniquely highest priority in each case, this fact is recorded. CoffeeFilter can use this when calculating whether or not to mark a parse as ambiguous.
Fixed a small bug in the presentation of alternative parses when there is ambiguity. Nonterminal symbols in the alternative choices did not necessarily have the correct attributes.

listitem.para: CoffeeGrinder now carefully distinguishes between nonterminals with different attributes. This introduces new nonterminals into the grammar. These can be examined by calling resolveDuplicates on the SourceGrammar.

If, for example, you have two instances of a nonterminal “B” in the grammar, where one has a mark attribute of “^” and the other a mark attribute of “@”, after resolving duplicates there will be two nonterminals in the grammar, “B” and “B₁”. They will match the same inputs, but is now possible to distinguish between them in the parse forest.

One particular use for this feature is the priority attribute supported by CoffeeFilter. This attribute allows the grammar author to associate priorities with nonterminals in ambiguous grammars to guide the parse.
All of the infrastructure associated with “pruning” nonterminals that lead to ε has been removed. (It hasn’t actually be used for at least a couple of releases.)
